awd_abstract_narration:
The recent explosion in worldwide data together with the end of Moore's Law and the near-term limits of silicon-based data storage being reached are driving an urgent need for alternative forms of computing and data storage/retrieval platforms. In particular, exabyte-scale datasets are increasingly being generated by the biological sciences and engineering disciplines including genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and high-resolution imaging, as well as disparate other scientific fields including climate science, ecology, astronomy, oceanography, sociology, and meteorology, amongst others. In this data revolution, the continuously increasing size of these datasets requires a concomitant increase in available computational power to store, process, and harness them, which is driving a need for revolutionary new, alternative substrates for, and forms of, computing and data storage. Unlike traditional data storage and computing materials such as silicon, the human brain offers a remarkable ability to sense, store, retrieve, and compute information in a manner that is unrivaled by any human-made material. In this research project, analogous modes of information sensing, data storage, retrieval, and computation will be explored in non-traditional computing molecular systems and materials. The over-arching goal of the research is to discover revolutionary new modes of data storage/retrieval, sensing, and computation that rival conventional silicon-based technology, for deployment to benefit society broadly across all domains of data science. Graduate students and postdocs across five institutions will be trained and mentored in a highly interdisciplinary manner to attain this goal and prepare the next-generation of data scientists, chemists, physicists, and engineers to harness the ongoing data revolution. The research will be disseminated to a broad community through news outlets and integration of high school student internships in participating research laboratories. 

Large-scale datasets from spatial-temporal calcium imaging of the mouse brain will be recorded into DNA-based, nanoparticle-based, and phononic 2D and 3D soft and hard materials. Continuous spatial-temporal data will first be transformed into discrete data for mapping onto DNA-conjugated fluorophore networks, dynamic barcoded nanoparticle networks, and phononic 2D and 3D materials. Sensing, computation, and data storage/retrieval will be demonstrated as proofs-of-principle in exploiting the chemical properties of molecular networks and materials to recover the encoded neuronal datasets and their sensing and computing processes. Success with any of these three prototypical materials would revolutionize the ability to encode arbitrarily complex, large-scale datasets into complex molecular systems, with the potential to scale across diverse data domains and materials frameworks. The investigators' Autonomous Computing Materials framework will thereby enable the encoding of arbitrary "big data" sets into diverse materials for data storage, sensing, and computing. This project maximizes opportunities for disruptive new computing and data science concepts to emerge from a multi-disciplinary, collaborative team spanning data science, neuroscience, materials science, chemistry, physics, and biological engineering. 

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity, and is jointly supported by HDR and the Division of Chemistry within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the collaborative project was to offer a transformative data science approach to map functional neuronal datasets to emergent properties of soft and hard materials including DNA-based assemblies, patchy nanoparticle assemblies, and phononic configurations. Data-driven computational procedures for designing and exploring emergent sensing, storage, and computing properties of DNA-based, nanoparticle-based, and phononic ensembles will be realized to encode these properties more generally in 1D, 2D, and 3D materials.

The project is divided into one cross-cutting theme and three research thrusts as follows:

  1. Theme E: Learning equivalent autonomy through data analysis.
  2. Research Thrust 1: DNA nanostructures and origami
  3. Research Thrust 2: Patchy nanoparticles
  4. Research Thrust 3: Phononic materials assembly

Theme E is jointly developed at the Ohio State University (OSU) and the University of California-San Diego (UCSD) while the three thrusts are being explored at three primary institutions namely Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Johns Hopkins University (JHU) and University of Colorado Boulder (UCB). Given the highly interdisciplinary nature of this grant, each thrust, and the cross-cutting theme is explored in close collaboration with teams across institutions. Thus, while the report will be organized topically per the activities enumerated above, the contribution of each site will be suitably highlighted.

The primary aim of the activities performed at UCB was to analyze the information stored in phononic/vibrational properties of solid-state materials and develop materials design principles to control the properties. To that end, a physics-aware machine learning (ML) model has been established that predicts phononic properties of complex heterogeneous nanostructured materials. The ML model is trained on the data obtained from atomistic modeling of small model structures that are part of these complex nanostructures. Silicon-germanium based nanostructured materials are chosen for proof-of-concept demonstrations since they are prevalent in modern computing devices and for which large-scale fabrication techniques already exist, such as fin field-effect transistors (finFET) and similar gate-all-around (GAA) architectures (e.g. nanosheets/nanowires). This way the project outcomes are also directly applicable to predict phononic/thermal properties of modern computing devices. Atomistic approaches used to describe the subject systems include atomistic equilibrium (EMD) and non-equilibrium molecular dynamics (NEMD) to model the dynamic atom trajectories and lattice dynamics (LD) to provide information about the phonon modes of the materials. The results of EMD and NEMD simulations are used to determine the vibrational and thermodynamic properties of the system and are combined with the results of LD calculations to determine the relative contributions that various phonon modes make to the overall atomic dynamics. The results of LD calculations are further used to explore the effects of nanoscale confinement on the phonon modes and their properties in a nanostructured material. The data generated using these approaches are used to develop machine learning models to (i) identify structure-phononic property relationships in small model systems and (ii) predict such relationships in complex heterogeneous nanostructured materials. The relationships are established using random forest (RF) algorithms and a recursive neural network (RNN).

Using the atomistic simulations and the ML models, we established that phonon modes of nanoengineered materials can be confined to specific spatial regions or guided along chosen directions through the selective design of nanoscale structures. Controlling phonons in desired spatial regions is essential for using phonons as information storage. The developed ML models, are successful at predicting thermal and vibrational environments (including in frequency space) from the knowledge of geometric and compositional features of the material structures of varied complexity. The success of the RNN algorithm has been found to depend on the features selected for training. Selected set of features inputs results in remarkably good predictions of the temperature profile and vibrational density of states. We further developed the models to learn and predict the relationship between atomic structures and electronic properties and, to establish a bridge between theoretical prediction and experimental data.

Based on preliminary data, analytic workflows, and simulations described above, the UCB group has organized/ is in the process of organizing manuscripts on the following topics: (1) Demonstrated the application of ML approaches to predict electronic properties of fabricated systems bypassing expensive first-principles computations. This manuscript was published in npj Computational Materials by members of the Neogi laboratories. The published article was highlighted in the IEEE Spectrum magazine: M. Hutson, ?Physicists Teach AI to Simulate Atomic Clusters: Physics-informed machine learning might help verify microchips," IEEE Spectrum, 02 Jul 2021; (2) Description of relationships between nanoscale structures and phonon modes: Atomistic modeling of phonon modes, their spatial location and propagation properties contributing to non-uniform thermal behavior in nanoengineered systems. (in preparation); (3) Phononic/thermal properties of semiconductor nanostructures via physics-informed machine learning: Identification of key physical descriptors that predict thermal and phononic properties in semiconductor materials guided by physics input. (in preparation); (4) Forward and inverse machine learning model to interpret spectroscopy data and design nanostructured materials with desired electronic properties. (in preparation);


Last Modified: 05/25/2022
Modified by: Sanghamitra Neogi

Image
  • Physics-aware machine learning model for phononic property prediction of complex nanostructures; The input includes atomistic properties (left), the descriptors are obtained using Voronoi tessellations (middle) and the representative predicted temperatures (right) are as shown.
    Sanghamitra Neogi
    Copyrighted
    Sanghamitra Neogi
    Machine learning model for phononic property prediction

Research      Thrust 1: DNA nanostructures and origami
Research      Thrust 2: Patchy nanoparticles
Research      Thrust 3: Phononic materials assembly
